Region specific rules are in place that range from staggering in-person teaching, mask requirements, and mask recommendations. 16 Sept twelve regions are coming out of lockdown but other areas of AUS remain in lockdown with a stay-at-home order. Under stay-at-home there is a closure of retail businesses for all but essential businesses. The goods and services must be picked up within the local government area where you live, or within 5km of where you live but not in another area of concern.     In the twelve areas coming out of lockdown restrictions are still in place: Retail stores can reopen under the one person per 4sqm rule. Personal services such as hairdressers and nail salons can open with one person per 4sqm, capped at five clients per premises.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210920193638/https://www.nsw.gov.au/media-releases/changes-to-stay-at-home-orders-for-regional-nsw-local-government-areas    https://web.archive.org/web/20210920194523/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/affected-area

Targeted regions have canceled events to comply with stay-at-home orders. New starting 20 September, those who are fully vaccinated and over 16 years old can attend an outdoor gathering in a public space of up to 5 people for exercise or outdoor recreation. Previously vaccination was not considered. Those who are not fully vaccinated can attend an outdoor gathering in a public space with 1 other person that you do not live with, or your nominated visitor ("singles bubble") for exercise or outdoor recreation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210920195542/https://www.nsw.gov.au/media-releases/restrictions-to-ease-lgas-of-concern  https://web.archive.org/web/20210920194117/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/affected-regions

Starting 20 September, those who live alone no longer have to register their nominated visitor ('singles bubble') with Service NSW. Although the registration is lifted, these 'nominated visitors' can only live either in a local government area of concern or Greater Sydney.    Continuing policy restrictions are in place for regions under stay-at-home order where visiting another person is not a reasonable excuse to leave your home and you must not allow a person to visit your home.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210920194523/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/affected-area

No new policy. Continuing from 23 June 2021 capacity has been decreased on all public transport modes. Continuing from early September many regions are on stay-at-home orders with exceptions for reasonable, essential excuses. 16 September stay-at-home orders will be lifted for Bega, Blayney, Bogan, Cabonne, Dungog, Forbes, Muswellbrook, Narrabri, Parkes, Singleton, Snowy Monaro and Upper Hunter Local Government Areas (LGAs) from 1pm. Stay-at-home orders will be introduced for the Albury and Lismore LGAs from 6pm 16 Sept for one week, due to an increased COVID-19 public health risk.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210920193638/https://www.nsw.gov.au/media-releases/changes-to-stay-at-home-orders-for-regional-nsw-local-government-areas    https://web.archive.org/web/20210920194117/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/affected-regions#visitors-to-a-residence

From 20 September, stay-at-home conditions are slightly relaxed. There is now no limit on the duration of outdoor exercise and recreation (previously a two-hour limit); Outdoor gatherings of up to five fully vaccinated people (not including children aged 12 and under) will be allowed in a personâs LGA or within 5km of home (previously only fully vaccinated household members could gather outdoors, or up to two fully vaccinated people from different households); Shopping, exercise and outdoor recreation can be done 5km from home or within your LGA (previously only 5km from home); Attend a small wedding (maximum 11 people) in Greater Sydney as a guest (previously only allowed in their LGA); and A personâs singleâs bubble buddy can live in Greater Sydney (previously must have resided within 5km of a personâs home). A person from a LGA of concern can also now be a buddy for someone in Greater Sydney.    From 20 September 2021 stay-at-home rules are in place for the local government area of Cowra until Tuesday 28 September 2021. The stay at home orders apply to anyone who has been in Cowra from 13 September 2021.    Continuing from early September many regions are on stay-at-home orders with exceptions for reasonable, essential excuses. Stay-at-home orders remain in place in the following local government areas â Bathurst Regional, Bourke, Brewarrina, City of Broken Hill, Central Coast, Central Darling, City of Cessnock, Dubbo Regional, Eurobodalla, Gilgandra, Goulburn Mulwarre, Kiama, City of Lake Macquarie, City of Lithgow, City of Maitland, Mid-Western Regional, Narromine, City of Newcastle, City of Orange, Port Stephens, Queanbeyan-Palerang Regional, City of Shellharbour, City of Shoalhaven, Walgett and Wingecarribee.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210920195542/https://www.nsw.gov.au/media-releases/restrictions-to-ease-lgas-of-concern  https://web.archive.org/web/20210920194523/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/affected-area

No new policies. In areas of stay-at-home orders, you must carry a face mask with you at all times when you leave your home and wear a face mask when required. In areas where stay-at-home orders are easing masks remain mandatory for all indoor public venues, including public transport, front-of-house hospitality, retail and business premises, on planes and at airports. National policy recommends wearing a surgical mask when you are in the same room as the sick person. The sick person should also wear a mask when other people are in the same room.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210920194523/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/affected-area    https://web.archive.org/web/20210920193638/https://www.nsw.gov.au/media-releases/changes-to-stay-at-home-orders-for-regional-nsw-local-government-areas    https://web.archive.org/web/20210916202421/https://www.health.gov.au/news/health-alerts/novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov-health-alert/how-to-protect-yourself-and-others-from-coronavirus-covid-19/physical-distancing-for-coronavirus-covid-19

In areas where stay-at-home orders are easing masks remain mandatory for all indoor public venues, including public transport, front-of-house hospitality, retail and business premises, on planes and at airports. National policy recommends wearing a surgical mask when you are in the same room as the sick person. The sick person should also wear a mask when other people are in the same room.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210924160129/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/affected-area    https://web.archive.org/web/20210920193638/https://www.nsw.gov.au/media-releases/changes-to-stay-at-home-orders-for-regional-nsw-local-government-areas    https://web.archive.org/web/20210916202421/https://www.health.gov.au/news/health-alerts/novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov-health-alert/how-to-protect-yourself-and-others-from-coronavirus-covid-19/physical-distancing-for-coronavirus-covid-19

No changes.    On 07 August, Brunei detected its first local Covid-19 cases in over a year, all of which were unlinked to previously-known imported cases. Hence, Brunei has decided to tighten Covid measures, including instituting the closure of schools.    Per the press release of 07 Aug by the Ministry of Health,    "With the consent of His Majesty the Sultan and Yang Di-Pertuan of Brunei Darussalam, it is hereby announced that the following control measures are reinstated for two weeks with immediate effect:    ...    3. Online learning will commenced for schools, other educational institutions, tuition classes, music classes and special needs classes."    Although it is initially unclear whether this directive applies to universities, Universiti Brunei Darussalam, the country's largest university, instituted Covid-19 shutdown measures on 9th August.    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL  See Universiti Brunei Darussalam (UBD)'s Covid-19 update page, archived at https://archive.vn/MKajg

See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL  See Universiti Brunei Darussalam (UBD)'s Covid-19 update page, archived at https://archive.vn/MKajg

No significant changes since the general tightening of measures on the 9th of August, except for the suspension of most in-patient dental procedures and services.    Measures were further tightened, after the discovery of more local cases on the 8th and 9th of August.    Per the press release of 09 Aug by the Ministry of Health, written in Malay,    "ii) All officers and staff, whether government or private are required to do work-from-home. Only really needed staff are allowed to go out to work such as,    frontline workers (health sector, security sector, hospitality sector, transport sector)  daily necessities sector (food, retail business)  facilities and utilities sector (electricity, water, telecommunications)  officers at the borders and entrances to Brunei Darussalam  oil and gas and downstream sectors  development sector  agri-food and forestry sectors"    See the Ministry of Health's initial press release, archived at https://archive.vn/jK4EU  See the Ministry of Health's press release on dental procedures (dated 15th August), archived at https://archive.vn/BAxD8

No changes.    Measures were further tightened, after the discovery of more local cases on the 8th and 9th of August.    Per the press release of 09 Aug by the Ministry of Health, written in Malay,    "i) Any public gathering is not allowed. However, exceptions are allowed as follows:    A group of 15 people for funeral management (not COVID-19).  A group of 5 people for the marriage ceremony."    Additionally, "iii) Leaving the house without a significant purpose is not allowed. Only two people from one family are allowed out of the house to buy daily necessities."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/jK4EU

No change. The only country-specific exception to the total travel ban is the Reciprocal Green Lane with Singapore, which has resumed with effect from 12th July (https://archive.vn/Eevqo). Other foreigners can only enter Brunei under specific essential travel circumstances (see below).    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated 23 Sep, foreigners that do not have a valid reason to enter are banned from entering.    Entry and Exit Requirements:        Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?  No.          Effective September 15, 2020, foreign citizens who meet certain requirements may enter Brunei for essential travel only.  All other foreign citizens are barred from entering or transiting Brunei by air, land, or sea.  Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for the latest information.          Citizens, permanent residents, and other residents of Brunei, including foreign citizens who hold a green identity card, require approval from the Prime Ministerâs Office in order to leave the country. This policy does not apply to tourists or other visitors who do not hold Bruneian government-issued identity cards.  Residents may apply for permission to leave the country by completing an online application at the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office.          Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.      Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry?  Yes.          Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for more information regarding Bruneiâs pre-departure testing requirements.      Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?  Yes.          Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.      Extensions of social visits, professional visits, or business visits while already in Brunei can be made directly with the Visa, Visit and Diplomatic Section, Department of Immigration and National Registration.  Visit the website of the Department of Immigration and National Registration for more information.    ---    Per the Entry Travel Pass requirements, last updated 02 Oct 2020,    The Entry Travel Pass may be issued for the following individuals:  â¢ Essential business travel (including official travel)  â¢ Students  â¢ Individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment  â¢ Compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other  immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.  Applications will be reviewed for considerations on a case-to-case basis by authorities.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/sd7pt  See the Prime Minister Office's guidelines on Entry Travel Pass applications, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/j0vr278nkt9dfh4/BRN-20201002-PMO-Guidelines_EntryTravelPassApp.pdf

See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/cGZuW  See the Prime Minister Office's guidelines on Entry Travel Pass applications, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/j0vr278nkt9dfh4/BRN-20201002-PMO-Guidelines_EntryTravelPassApp.pdf

No change. The only country-specific exception to the total travel ban is the Reciprocal Green Lane with Singapore, which has resumed with effect from 12th July (https://archive.vn/Eevqo). Other foreigners can only enter Brunei under specific essential travel circumstances (see below).    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated 05 Oct, foreigners that do not have a valid reason to enter are banned from entering.    Entry and Exit Requirements:        Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?  No.          Effective September 15, 2020, foreign citizens who meet certain requirements may enter Brunei for essential travel only.  All other foreign citizens are barred from entering or transiting Brunei by air, land, or sea.  Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for the latest information.          Citizens, permanent residents, and other residents of Brunei, including foreign citizens who hold a green identity card, require approval from the Prime Ministerâs Office in order to leave the country. This policy does not apply to tourists or other visitors who do not hold Bruneian government-issued identity cards.  Residents may apply for permission to leave the country by completing an online application at the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office.          Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.      Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry?  Yes.          Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for more information regarding Bruneiâs pre-departure testing requirements.      Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?  Yes.          Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.      Extensions of social visits, professional visits, or business visits while already in Brunei can be made directly with the Visa, Visit and Diplomatic Section, Department of Immigration and National Registration.  Visit the website of the Department of Immigration and National Registration for more information.    ---    Per the Entry Travel Pass requirements, last updated 02 Oct 2020,    The Entry Travel Pass may be issued for the following individuals:  â¢ Essential business travel (including official travel)  â¢ Students  â¢ Individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment  â¢ Compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other  immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.  Applications will be reviewed for considerations on a case-to-case basis by authorities.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/cY1bs  See the Prime Minister Office's guidelines on Entry Travel Pass applications, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/j0vr278nkt9dfh4/BRN-20201002-PMO-Guidelines_EntryTravelPassApp.pdf

No changes/deviation; Brunei continues to maintain a systematic, coordinated public campaign re: COVID.    The government continues to maintain an overall website where citizens can access any information related to COVID.   https://archive.vn/PwOIW    There is also an overall site on the Ministry of Health's website pertaining to Covid-19 vaccination (the programme, FAQ, public health messaging).  https://archive.vn/5UFPG    The Ministry of Health continues to update COVID case numbers almost daily (although in most circumstances, daily). See, for example, 23 Sep (https://archive.vn/EfjJC)    No updates were missing.

No change.    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 23 Sep,    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Brunei?  Yes.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours?  Yes.  Members of the public who need to undergo a swab test for any reason are advised to go to the Sports Complex, Raja Isteri Pengiran Anak Saleha (RIPAS) Hospital, or other health centers where testing is provided.  The testing fee for foreigners is BND $200 [sic, current cost as per Brunei's Ministry of Health is BND $50].  More information is available here.  Test results will be delivered through SMS.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/sd7pt  See the Ministry of Health press release on testing cost (22 May), archived at https://archive.vn/kU9pS

No changes.    On 07 August, Brunei detected its first local Covid-19 cases in over a year, all of which were unlinked to previously-known imported cases. Hence, Brunei has decided to tighten Covid measures, including instituting mandatory mask measures.    Per the press release of 07 Aug by the Ministry of Health,    "Meanwhile, to address the concerns on the spread of Delta variant around the world, including in Brunei Darussalam, the Ministry of Health would also like to inform the public on the changes in the face mask guidelines:    1. Face masks are required be worn at all times, especially indoors or in crowded places either indoor or outdoor.  2. Face mask must cover the wearer's nose and mouth.  3. This directive is applicable to all individuals regardless of their vaccination status."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL

Vaccination groups: Phase 1, 2 and 3 under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy  Phase 1: Frontline workers; senior citizens aged 60 and above; students studying abroad;  and  Phase 2: teachers; childcare centre staff/childcare workers; adults at high risk or suffering from chronic diseases  and  Phase 3: individuals aged 18 years and above    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV); Moderna (elasomeran/mRNA-1273)    NOTE: The temporary halt for people getting their first doses due to an unexpected supply issue for vaccines was lifted on 23rd September, after China donated more Sinopharm vaccines to Brunei. "A total of 100,000 doses of Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine and 102,400 syringes donated by the Chinese government arrived at Brunei on Sept. 12." "Australia and Japan [have also] both pledged 100,000 doses of AstraZeneca each", with Brunei offering the AstraZeneca vaccine as the default first shot.    Brunei's Phase 3 of its Vaccination Strategy, for individuals aged 18 years and above, commenced on 05 July. "[Individuals] who wish to get the COVID-19 vaccinations during Phase 3 are required to reserve a slot".    See:  The Ministry of Health's press release "Registration For The National Vaccination Program For Covid-19 For The Phase Three" (dated 01 Jul), archived at https://archive.vn/M1nb1  The Ministry of Health's press release "Registration For The National Vaccination Program For COVID-19 For The Second Phase" (dated 14 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/nzwGg  The Scoop's report, entitled "Phase 2 of COVID-19 vaccination starts on June 21" (dated 14 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/qgiQm  The Ministry of Health's press release "COVID-19 Moderna vaccine arrived in Brunei Darussalam" (dated 20 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/2onLe  Borneo Bulletin's report, entitled "Second phase of COVID-19 vaccination begins" (dated 22 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/XhM2i  The Star Online's report, entitled "Brunei: Over 76, 000 received Covid-19 vaccination as country goes 417 without local cases" (dated 28 Jun), archived at https://archive.is/7F2bK  Xinhua's report, entitled "Brunei continues COVID-19 vaccination with China's Sinopharm donations" (dated 16 Sep), archived at https://archive.vn/k5deH  The Scoop's report, entitled "MoH: Two jabs 83% effective in preventing COVID-19 infection" (dated 15 Sep), archived at https://archive.vn/5NITD  The Scoop's report, entitled "AstraZeneca is now Bruneiâs default vaccine" (dated 18 Sep), archived at https://archive.vn/SbAOq

No change in policy since last iteration.    Additionally, under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy, senior citizens of age 60 and above belong to Phase 1, alongside Bruneians studying abroad and frontliners.    The advice for elderly people to be protected via vaccinations was reiterated on 07 Aug, when Brunei first detected its first local transmission cases in over a year. "Individuals who have not yet received COVID-19 vaccination especially those at high risk such as the elderly and those with chronic diseases are advised to reserve an vaccination slot as soon as possible. Walk-ins at vaccination centres will only be allowed for senior citizens aged 60 and above or individuals with special needs." A country's top health official admits that most pupils are unlikely to return to school before next year, which is set to be after Fiji opens its borders to tourists.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211004205845/https://www.abc.net.au/radio-australia/programs/pacificbeat/covid-vaccines-fiji-school-kids-no-timeframe-schools-reopening/13549196

Restrictions on movement remain in place in Viti Levu. The capital, Suva is part of a large containment area reaching to Nausori where restrictions are in place. Some non-essential businesses have resumed operations alongside essential businesses following approval from government provided that they follow COVID-19 safety protocols.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211004210351/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/fiji/coronavirus

https://web.archive.org/web/20211004210351/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/fiji/coronavirus  Most public places in Viti Levu are closed, other than essential businesses including supermarkets and pharmacies. Nightclubs remain closed and you must abide by the nationwide curfew which need you to remain in your home or accommodation between 6pm and 4am.
https://web.archive.org/web/20211004210351/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/fiji/coronavirus

Travel restrictions have been in place in Fiji following a COVID-19 outbreak. Scheduled international and domestic passenger flights have been suspended though some outbound âSpecial flightsâ are being operated by Fiji Airways. The main island of Viti Levu has two âcontainment zonesâ one covering the Greater Suva Area and one covering the Nadi/Lautoka area in the west. Travel into and out of these zones is restricted. The Fijian Government continues with targeted of lockdown of areas where existing clusters of COVID-19 exist. Some boat services to and from Viti Levu remain suspended but some journeys have been approved under tight controls.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211004210351/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/fiji/coronavirus

The Fijian government is encouraging most people to work from home, and to leave their houses only if essential.  A nationwide curfew is in effect from 6pm to 4am each night.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211004211544/https://www.fiji.travel/covid-19/coronavirus-covid-19-information-fiji  The Fijian government is encouraging most people to work from home, and to leave their houses only if essential.
https://web.archive.org/web/20211004211544/https://www.fiji.travel/covid-19/coronavirus-covid-19-information-fiji

Fijiâs border is currently closed, and travel restrictions remain in place. With the exception of repatriation flights for Fijian residents, there are no international tourist or business flights into the country.    There are currently two programs which allow visitors into the country under special circumstances. These include the Luxury Vacation in Paradise program for private island buyouts as well as the âBlue Laneâ program for private yachts and superyachts.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211004211544/https://www.fiji.travel/covid-19/coronavirus-covid-19-information-fiji

A one-off COVID-19 relief for Fiji National Provident Fund members impacted by the lockdown restrictions in the Western Division will open from Monday 26 April 2021.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211004212024/https://myfnpf.com.fj/2021/04/20/covid-19-lockdown-relief/

https://web.archive.org/web/20211004211325/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  The authorities have announced two major fiscal stimulus packages in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, one on March 26 and one on July 17. The first package entailed up to FJ$1 billion (8.7 percent of GDP) in supplemental expenditures on public health, lump sum payments through the Fiji National Provident Fund (FNPF), tax and tariff reductions, and loan repayment holidays (up to F$ 400 million of the total envelope) aim at protecting public health, supporting the economy and ensuring food security.
The FIji government is involved in an coordinated and aggressive public campaign to contain the COVID-19 pandemic.  https://archive.vn/hsibL

Priority if testing is for symptomatic people, high-risk people such as asymptomatic close contacts of a case of COVID-19, or international travellers, who have completed 14 days of the total of 28 days of quarantine. Asymptomatic healthcare workers who have completed 14 days quarantine after directly caring for confirmed cases and patients with acute respiratory illness may also be tested.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210531142124/http://www.health.gov.fj/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/CRITERIA-FOR-TESTING-FOR-COVID-19-FOR-FIJI_upload.pdf

As of Sep, 21, ten cities are under level 4 community activity restrictions. These are Aceh Tamiang, Pidie, Bangka Belitung, Padang, Banjar Baru, Balikpapan, Kutai Kartanegara, Tarakan, and Bulungan. Source: Garda World   Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20211003223803/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/526591/indonesia-authorities-extend-covid-19-restrictions-and-downgrade-all-level-4-localities-in-java-and-bali-through-oct-4-update-87     Under level 4, employee in non-essential industries must continue to telecommunicate. Staff from essential sector can work on site at various capacity limit; essential service and office administration workers may work on-site at 50% and 25% capacity respectively. Supermarkets can open until 21:00 at 50% capacity. Food stalls and street vendors may operate with health protocol in place; dine-in is allowed at a maximum of three customers. Restaurants and cafes are limited to takeaway services but may offer dine-in services of up to 25% capacity with only two guests per table if situated outdoors. All food establishments can operate through 20:00 daily with a maximum meal time of 30 minutes for dine-in customers. Most retail establishments and recreational facilities remain closed. Places of worship may operate at 50% capacity or with a cap of 50 people. Domestic long-distance travel restrictions remain in place. Individuals must provide a vaccination card indicating at least one dose of the COVID-19 vaccine and a negative result from a PCR test taken within 48 hours of departure for air travel. People traveling by land or sea must provide a vaccination card indicating at least one dose of the COVID-19 vaccine or a negative rapid antigen test result taken within 48 hours. Official may randomly subject some passengers to tests. All air and sea domestic travellers must register on the Health Alert Card (eHAC) mobile application before travel; official advice travellers to download the PeduliLindungi contact tracing application. Expected timeframe Sep,21 to Oct,05. Source: Garda World  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20211003223803/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/526591/indonesia-authorities-extend-covid-19-restrictions-and-downgrade-all-level-4-localities-in-java-and-bali-through-oct-4-update-87

The Indonesian government has prohibited foreign visitors from transiting and traveling to Indonesian territory unless they are in possession of a valid residence permit or certain classes of visas. International travellers entering Indonesia will be required to show proof of full vaccination against COVID-19. International travellers who cannot be vaccinated due to medical conditions and children under 12 years of age are exempted from showing proof of vaccination.   Travellers are required to have a negative COVID-19 PCR test obtained within 72-hours of their departure. Travellers are required to quarantine at their own expense at a government designated hotel for eight days and are required to take two mandatory PCR tests while in hotel quarantine before proceeding to their destination. In the event of a positive test result travellers will be required to stay at quarantine for 14 to 32 days at their own expense. Source: United State embassy Indonesia. Seven COVID-19 vaccines have been approved under âemergency use authorizationâ to be used in Indonesia: CoronaVac (Sinovac), COVID-19 Bio Farma, AstraZeneca, Sinopharm, Moderna, Comirnaty (Pfizer and BioNTech), and Sputnik-V. Source: ANTARA news  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20211004173439/https://en.antaranews.com/news/192585/over-53-million-indonesians-receive-second-covid-19-dose     As of Sep,29, 89.8 million first shots, accounting for 43.1 percent of the target, and 50.4 million second shots, or 24.2 percent of the target have been administered. Source: ANTARA news  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20211004174731/https://en.antaranews.com/news/191693/indonesians-prepare-to-learn-to-live-with-covid-19  Third booster dose have been administered to health workers, and as of October, 4; the number of health workers received a third dose was 962,619. He assured that the government will continue to administer vaccines, including to the general public, especially to those 12 years and over, pregnant women, and elderly people. Schools in many regions have resumed in-person learning, however, school attendance is largely part-time through staggering grades or shortening classes to reduce the number of students on-site at any one time. All other days of the week for students are spent in online lessons.  For many wards and prefectures, online schooling is also a voluntary option available to students and parents during the state of emergency.  From September 20 to 26, all public schools in Tokyo Metropolitan Area announced there will be a temporary suspension of in-person learning during Silver Week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910022721/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210909/k10013252101000.html (Silver Week suspension in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210918025123/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210913/k10013256991000.html (summary of school attendance in Tokyo's 23 wards)

During "Silver Week", all public schools in Tokyo Metropolitan Area from September 20 to 26 will be temporarily closed to in-person learning. Students are expected to return on Sep 27.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910022721/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210909/k10013252101000.html (Silver Week suspension in Tokyo)

The a week suspension of in-person learning for students in the Metropolitan Tokyo area has ended and all classes have resumed inline with other prefectures across Japan.  The government of Japan has decided all emergency and priority measures will be lighted for all prefectures on October 1. Included, all schools across Japan currently stagger attendance by grades or classes will resume full capacity in-person learning on October 1. Continued focus on sanization, contact tracing within schools, and restrictions on club activities or school excursions will remain. Individual schools also have the jurisdiction to temporarily close due to infection outbreaks on a case-by-case basis.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910022721/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210909/k10013252101000.html (Silver Week)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003032546/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210928/k10013280271000.html (Resumption of school)

On October 1, Japan lifts emergency and priority measures for all prefectures and will undergo a precautionary period for one month. From Oct 1 to Oct 24, Tokyo will undergo a period with various lighter restrictions. For Okinawa, the precautionary period is between Oct 1 to Oct 31.    Many prefectures and school districts have been staggering class attendance but will begin in-person learning at full capacity due to measures being lifted. Schools are to continue undergoing stringent sanitation and infection prevention measures, restricting club activities with high risk of infection and suspension of all school excursions. Students with illness symptoms are not to attend schools. Individual schools may also have the jurisdiction to close due to in-school outbreaks on a school-by-school basis.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190427/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003191110/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211001/k10013285601000.html (resumption of classes)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190946/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211001/k10013286091000.html (resumption of classes)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190552/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/636/20210928/torikumi.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190640/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/638/20211001.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190745/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0928taisyohoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa)

No change to previous policy. All emergency and priority measures will continue until September 30.  State of emergency measures extended from Sep 12 to Sep 30: Hokkaido, Miyagi, Gifu, Aichi, Mie, Shiga, Okayama, Hiroshima, Okinawa, Tokyo, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Osaka, Ibaraki, Tochigi, Gunma, Shizuoka, Kyoto, Hyogo, Fukuoka.  Prority measures extended from Sep 12 to Sep 30: Miyazaki, Kumamoto, Kagawa, Kagoshima.  Priority measures will lift on Sep 12 for: Toyama, Yamanashi, Ehime, Kochi, Saga, and Nagasaki.    Okinawa will continue to close public facilities effective until Sep 30.  For prefectures under emergency orders: nightclubs, cabarets, karaoke parlors and bars not licensed as a restaurant must close. Restaurants may service customers provided restaurants follow shorten business hours from 5am to 8pm. All other businesses and events should also operate between 5am to 8pm.  For prefectures under priority measures: Alcohol restrictions have been lifted allowing alcohol to be served until 7:30pm. Local governments also request all businesses operate between 5am to 9pm with the exception of restaurants which should operate between 5am to 8pm. Meeting halls, theatres, recreational facilities, places of tourism or leisure all must comply within these guidelines for shorten business hours.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210918001040/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910005628/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210909/k10013250961000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910013547/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/484/20210909/20210909.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910013317/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0909taishohoshin.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210918004444/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0909eigo.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910015844/https://www.pref.kumamoto.jp/soshiki/30/104632.html

On October 1, Japan lifts emergency and priority measures for all prefectures and will undergo a precautionary period for one month. From Oct 1 to Oct 24, Tokyo will undergo a period with various lighter restrictions. For Okinawa, the precautionary period is between Oct 1 to Oct 31.    All businesses including bars and nightclubs are able to reopen provided businesses serving alcohol receives a certificate of inspection for infection control by the Ministry of Health, however karaoke equipment is requested not to be used. During the precautionary period, all businesses are requested to operate at shortened business hours between 5:00AM to 9:00PM with alcohol permitted to being served 11:00AM to 8:00PM (in Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, and Okinawa). In Tochigi, alcohol may be served until 7:30PM; and in Okinawa, acohol may be served until 7:00PM.  Businesses are asked to reduce the number of workers in the office by 70% through utilizing remote methods of work and to request employees finish work by 8:00PM.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190427/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193347/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210929/k10013281591000.html (restrictions in Kanto region)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193702/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210928/k10013281561000.html (restrictioins in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190552/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/636/20210928/torikumi.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190640/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/638/20211001.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190745/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0928taisyohoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa)

State of emergency measures extended from Sep 12 to Sep 30: Hokkaido, Miyagi, Gifu, Aichi, Mie, Shiga, Okayama, Hiroshima, Okinawa, Tokyo, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Osaka, Ibaraki, Tochigi, Gunma, Shizuoka, Kyoto, Hyogo, Fukuoka.  Prority measures extended from Sep 12 to Sep 30: Miyazaki, Kumamoto, Kagawa, Kagoshima.  Priority measures will lift on Sep 12 for: Toyama, Yamanashi, Ehime, Kochi, Saga, and Nagasaki.    Okinawa will continue their extended state of emergency until September 30, where events with a maximum of 1,000 people at 50% venue capacity may proceed to be held. Events with no spectators, however, are being recommended.  All other prefectures under emergency orders, events with a maximum of 5,000 people at a 50% venue capacity may proceed to be held.    For other prefectures under priority or no measures, if the gathering does not require loud cheering, the event may proceed at 100% facility capacity for a maximum of 5,000 people or less. For gatherings with loud cheering, the event may proceed at 50% facility capacity for a maximum of 5,000 people or less. All events must end at 9pm in prefectures with priority measures.  Local governments continue to encourage residents to stay home and to avoid going to crowded places or engaging in high risk activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210918001040/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910005628/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210909/k10013250961000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910013547/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/484/20210909/20210909.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910013317/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0909taishohoshin.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210918004444/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0909eigo.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910015844/https://www.pref.kumamoto.jp/soshiki/30/104632.html

On October 1, Japan lifts emergency and priority measures for all prefectures and will undergo a precautionary period for one month. From Oct 1 to Oct 24, Tokyo will undergo a period with various lighter restrictions. For Okinawa, the precautionary period is between Oct 1 to Oct 31.    During the precautionary period, all events are asked to be completed by 9:00PM. For events involving loud events, capacity is limited to 50% of the venue capacity and not exceed an upper limit of 10,000 people. For events with no loud voices, 100% of the venue capacity may be used but not exceed an upper limit of 5,000 people. In Okinawa, loud events are limited to 50% venue capacity and must not exceed 5,000 people.  Businesses are asked to reduce the number of workers in the office by 70% through utilizing remote methods of work and to request employees finish work by 8:00PM. Drinking gatherings at bars are asked to to be limited to 4 people per group.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190427/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193347/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210929/k10013281591000.html (restrictions in Kanto region)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193702/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210928/k10013281561000.html (restrictioins in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190552/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/636/20210928/torikumi.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190640/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/638/20211001.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190745/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0928taisyohoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa)

No change to previous policy. All emergency and priority measures will continue until September 30.  State of emergency measures extended from Sep 12 to Sep 30: Hokkaido, Miyagi, Gifu, Aichi, Mie, Shiga, Okayama, Hiroshima, Okinawa, Tokyo, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Osaka, Ibaraki, Tochigi, Gunma, Shizuoka, Kyoto, Hyogo, Fukuoka.  Prority measures extended from Sep 12 to Sep 30: Miyazaki, Kumamoto, Kagawa, Kagoshima.  Priority measures will lift on Sep 12 for: Toyama, Yamanashi, Ehime, Kochi, Saga, and Nagasaki.    Okinawa will continue their extended state of emergency until September 30, where events with a maximum of 1,000 people at 50% venue capacity may proceed to be held. Events with no spectators, however, are being recommended.  All other prefectures under emergency orders, events with a maximum of 5,000 people at a 50% venue capacity may proceed to be held.    For other prefectures under priority or no measures, if the gathering does not require loud cheering, the event may proceed at 100% facility capacity for a maximum of 5,000 people or less. For gatherings with loud cheering, the event may proceed at 50% facility capacity for a maximum of 5,000 people or less. All events must end at 9pm in prefectures with priority measures.  Local governments continue to encourage residents to stay home and to avoid going to crowded places or engaging in high risk activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210918001040/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910005628/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210909/k10013250961000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910013547/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/484/20210909/20210909.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910013317/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0909taishohoshin.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210918004444/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0909eigo.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910015844/https://www.pref.kumamoto.jp/soshiki/30/104632.html

Priority measures apply to: Ishikawa, Fukushima, Kumamoto, Kagawa, Kagoshima, Miyazaki, Miyagi, Okayama. On October 1, Japan lifts emergency and priority measures for all prefectures and will undergo a precautionary period for one month. From Oct 1 to Oct 24, Tokyo will undergo a period with various lighter restrictions. For Okinawa, the precautionary period is between Oct 1 to Oct 31.    During the precautionary period, all events are asked to be completed by 9:00PM. For events involving loud events, capacity is limited to 50% of the venue capacity and not exceed an upper limit of 10,000 people. For events with no loud voices, 100% of the venue capacity may be used but not exceed an upper limit of 5,000 people. In Okinawa, loud events are limited to 50% venue capacity and must not exceed 5,000 people.  Businesses are asked to reduce the number of workers in the office by 70% through utilizing remote methods of work and to request employees finish work by 8:00PM. Drinking gatherings at bars are asked to to be limited to 4 people per group.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190427/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193347/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210929/k10013281591000.html (restrictions in Kanto region)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193702/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210928/k10013281561000.html (restrictioins in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190552/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/636/20210928/torikumi.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190640/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/638/20211001.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190745/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0928taisyohoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa)

No change to previous policy as Japan lifts emergency and priority measures for all prefectures and will undergo a precautionary period for one month. From Oct 1 to Oct 24, Tokyo will undergo a period with various lighter restrictions. For Okinawa, the precautionary period is between Oct 1 to Oct 31.    During the precautionary period, all events are asked to be completed by 9:00PM. For events involving loud events, capacity is limited to 50% of the venue capacity or an upper limit of 10,000 people. For events with no loud voices, 100% of the venue capacity may be used but not exceed an upper limit of 5,000 people. In Tokyo and Okinawa, events are limited to 50% venue capacity and must not exceed 5,000 people.  Businesses are asked to reduce the number of workers in the office by 70% through utilizing remote methods of work and to request employees finish work by 8:00PM. Drinking gatherings at bars are asked to to be limited to 4 people per group.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008202753/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193347/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210929/k10013281591000.html (restrictions in Kanto region)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193702/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210928/k10013281561000.html (restrictioins in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190552/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/636/20210928/torikumi.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190640/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/638/20211001.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008195947/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1015635.html (Tokyo gathering restriction clarifications)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008200105/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1007taishohousin.pdf (Okinawa)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008200827/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0928eigo.pdf (Okinawa)

All public transportation continues to remain in operation.  Tokyo Metro has posted alternative commuter office hours during the Tokyo state of emergency. In addition, public information on cases among employees are updated as of Sep 17.  Regular service continues on Japan Rail with heightened prevention measures including increase ventilation, physical distancing, disinfection, wearing of masks, and preventing passengers from rotating seats.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210918041140/https://www.tokyometro.jp/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210918045434/https://www.tokyometro.jp/info/208126.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210906193947/https://www.tokyometro.jp/info/210446.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210918045111/https://www.westjr.co.jp/info/corona_taisaku.html

Ahead of "Silver Week" (week of September 20), the government of Japan is requesting citizens to avoid non-essential movement in an effort to lift the country's state of emergencies.  Okinawa is asking all residents to stop holding events and travelling to remote islands and non-essential movement to be reduce by 50%.  The Government of Japan continues to encourage residents to stay home and avoid areas or activities of high risk for infection.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210918000712/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210912/k10013255591000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210918001040/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910013547/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/484/20210909/20210909.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910013317/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0909taishohoshin.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210918004444/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0909eigo.pdf

Border closure for entry into Japan continues to be in place. Travel for tourism and other short-term purposes remain restricted, while all Visa-free travel is suspended.  For travellers who are granted exceptional status for entry, various countries will have differing quarantine and testing requirements on arrival corresponding to country/region designation by   variants of concern provided by the Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs (latest list of specialty measures for regions is updated as of Sep 17).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210918045920/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210918050209/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C125.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210918045959/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/

Border closure for entry into Japan continues to be in place. Travel for tourism and other short-term purposes remain restricted, while all Visa-free travel is suspended.  For travellers who are granted exceptional status for entry, various countries will have differing quarantine and testing requirements on arrival corresponding to country/region designation by   variants of concern provided by the Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs (latest list of specialty measures for regions is updated as of Sep 17).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210924205040/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210918050209/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C125.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924205024/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/

Border closure for entry into Japan continues to be in place. Travel for tourism and other short-term purposes remain restricted, while all Visa-free travel is suspended.  For travellers who are granted exceptional status for entry, various countries will have differing quarantine and testing requirements on arrival corresponding to country/region designation by variants of concern provided by the Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs (latest list of specialty measures for regions is updated as of Sep 27).  To be eligible for a shortened quarantine period, Japan has so far designated only Pfizer, AstraZeneca, and Moderna as valid certificates of vaccination. All certificates must be issued by the public institution from government or country of origin, and must be written in either Japanese or English containing the following information: name, date of birth, vaccine name or manufacturer, vaccination date, dose. In addition, 14-days or more must have passed from the second dose date.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003202905/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003203427/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C127.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003203141/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003203912/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/covid19/certificate_to_Japan.html

No change to previous policy. New subsidy application deadlines for July-Nov 2021 have been set for December 31, 2021 (support document revised as of Sep 9).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://archive.vn/etwSB (https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910192507/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf

No change to previous policy. New debt relief application deadlines for July-Nov 2021 have been set for December 31, 2021 (support document revised as of Sep 9).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free with the possibility of repayment exemption. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://archive.vn/etwSB (https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910192507/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://archive.vn/nf1P8 (https://corona.go.jp/action/)

No change to previous policy.  800,000 antigen test kits have been distributed to kindergartens, elementary, and middle schools for surveillance purposes for the start of the fall semester.  Antigen tests are limitedly available to eligible cluster cases when fast results are requested for a large number of people. Typically due to potential inaccuracies, negative antigen tests are re-tested via PCR.    PCR tests are conducted at medical institutions designated by prefectures for returnee patients, outpatients, and when a doctors deems the testing be necessary. In some areas, with the cooperation of regional medical associations, "regional outpatient/examination center" have been set up to carry out intensive examinations and to determine testing. While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210827194425/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210827/k10013227701000.html  https://archive.vn/FRGLT (https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html)  https://archive.vn/a9w6H (https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html)

No change to previous policy.  Antigen tests are limitedly available to eligible cluster cases when fast results are requested for a large number of people. Typically due to potential inaccuracies, negative antigen tests are re-tested via PCR.    PCR tests are conducted at medical institutions designated by prefectures for returnee patients, outpatients, and when a doctors deems the testing be necessary. In some areas, with the cooperation of regional medical associations, "regional outpatient/examination center" have been set up to carry out intensive examinations and to determine testing. No change to previous policy.  Antigen tests are limitedly available to eligible cluster cases when fast results are requested for a large number of people, e.g. schools. Typically due to potential inaccuracies, negative rapid antigen tests are re-tested via PCR.    PCR tests are conducted at medical institutions designated by prefectures for returnee patients, outpatients, and when a doctors deems the testing be necessary. In some areas, with the cooperation of regional medical associations, "regional outpatient/examination center" have been set up to carry out intensive examinations and to determine testing. While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee.    PCR tests, antigen tests, and antibody tests may be requested for asymptomatic individuals for the purposes of travel will however, be charged by laboratory facilities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (rapid antigent testing in schools)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205543/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205549/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205625/https://jp.usembassy.gov/services/pcr-testing-facilities-in-japan/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003205304/https://hiro-clinic.jp/

In Osaka, the aim for all close contact tracing is to be contacted within 2 days of case confirmation. However, due to current high rates of infection, it has taken an upwards of 4 days to be contacted.  There continues to be a reduction in ability to conduct full close contact tracing in Tokyo and Saitama due to the high number of infections. Close contact tracing has been overwhelmed and efforts have shifted to targeted/priority settings such as schools or elderly facilities.    For other prefectures, small-cluster contact tracing continues to be manually and comprehensively conducted, in addition to the utilization of the COVID-19 Contact-Confirming Application (COCOA).    https://archive.vn/uDBMq (https://www.sankeibiz.jp/macro/news/210907/mca2109070604003-n1.htm) (Osaka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210906201209/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210901/k10013237791000.html (Saitama)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823030440/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/national/20210821-OYT1T50023/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814022625/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210814/k10013201711000.html  https://archive.vn/4P16l (https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kansenkakudaiboushi-iryouteikyou.html)

On September 10, priority vaccination appointments for 18-39 year olds begin to open at the Osaka mass vaccination site with 6000 reservation slots filling up in 7 minutes after the booking system opens. Inoculation efforts for 18-39 year olds in the Tokyo and Osaka venues will be held until September 25 for a total of over 30,000 vaccinations for the younger generation.  In Shizuoka City, priority vaccinations also began being held for children ages 12+ and parents; for a total vaccination quota of more than 2,860 people.    Those who are eligible to be inoculated at the mass vaccination sites include 65+, pregnant women, and ages 18-39.  The government has announced that vaccine supply for 90% of those over 12 years old to be vaccinated twice will be available by early October. The government is also working on foundations of a certificate of vaccination.    As of Sep 10, 61.9% of the entire population (including children under age eligible for vaccination) has received at least one dose, and 49.8% of entire population has received two doses.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910195220/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210910/k10013253861000.html (Osaka mass vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210905234805/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210902/k10013239891000.html (Tokyo mass vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910195804/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210910/k10013253171000.html (Shizuoka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910195836/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910200346/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910200626/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00218.html

On September 11, priority inoculation for the younger generation (ages 18-39) begin in Osaka mass vaccination site.  Within Taito ward of Tokyo, efforts are being made to mass vaccinate those who are homeless to prevent spread of infection in vulnerable populations.  In Katsushika ward of Tokyo, priority vaccination of elementary school children and junior high school students begin in mass vaccination venues. Children who have a resident card from elementary 6th grade to junior high 3rd grade are eligible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210917235431/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210911/k10013254511000.html (Osaka youth vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210917235506/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210913/k10013257031000.html (Taito homeless vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210917235620/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210911/k10013255201000.html (Katsushika priority children vaccination)

On September 12, Joso city in Ibaraki prefecture begin focusing mass vaccination efforts towards foreign residents due to issues with language barrier and dissemination of information.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210917235830/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210912/k10013256271000.html

On September 13, healthcare workers in Toyanaka city, Osaka begin the dispatch of "vaccine cars," vehicles promoting vaccination and pop-up clinics towards younger generation in smaller neighbourhoods.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210918000405/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210913/k10013257101000.html

On September 17, in order to promote uptake of vaccination in individuals 39 years old and younger, Minato ward in Tokyo will be operating a weekend midnight vaccination clinic every Friday. This late-night operating clinic will allow those in the workforce who are worried about taking time off work due to potential next day side effects to be inoculated.    https://archive.vn/FHmXG

In Shinjuku Ward, the number of mass inoculation venues, which was 17 as of July, has been reduced to 10 due to the decrease in supply. To accomodate for the higher population of young people (18-39 year olds) in certain areas within Tokyo, the Japanese government will be redirecting supply from other locales to necessary wards in Tokyo.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210924175631/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210922/k10013272411000.html

As of September 26, at large scale vaccination sites in Tokyo and Osaka, there is surplus of vacant vaccination appointments available in the coming few weekdays for a total of 8100 spots still available for booking. The government is urging all residents above 18 years old to get vaccinated.  Priority vaccinations continue to be administered for junior high school students, high school students, and their families with children who are about to enter examination period. Priority vaccinations are also occurring for pregnant women and their families.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211002175553/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210925/k10013275931000.html (examinee vaccinations)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211002175629/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210925/k10013276631000.html (pregnancy vaccinations)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211002180024/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210927/k10013279131000.html (surplus appointments)

Due to the continued surplus in vacant slots at mass vaccination sites in Tokyo and Osaka, the Japanese government has lifted restrictions for young people priority bookings. All residents age 16+ are able to begin booking at mass vaccination sites on September 30 for slots beginning October 4. For junior and high school students age 12+, reservations will begin October 1 for slots starting October 4.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211002181039/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210929/k10013283021000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211002181528/https://www.fukushihoken.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/iryo/kansen/coronavaccine/daikibosesshu.html

In Osaka, an announcement was made that all Osakan mass vaccination sites will begin administering walk-in vaccinations (no reservations required) for resident age 16+ beginning October 4.    As of Oct 1, 70.4% of the total population in Japan (including those under the eligible age for vaccination) have received their first dose, with 59.8% of the total population having received both doses.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211002182119/https://osaka-mvc.com/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211002182806/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/

On October 4, walk-in (no reservation) vaccinations begin for residents 16 years old and up at mass vaccination venues in Osaka Prefecture.  On October 4, Tokyo begins vaccinating residents 12 years old and up for those who have reserved slots at mass vaccination sites in Tokyo Metropolitan Area.    Third dose vaccinations is being planned to begin in December 2021.  As of Oct 8, 72.8% of the total population in Japan (including those under the eligible age for vaccination) have received their first dose, with 63.1% of the total population having received both doses.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008213231/https://osaka-mvc.com/ (Osaka vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008213225/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211006/k10013294641000.html (Osaka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008213929/https://www.fukushihoken.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/iryo/kansen/coronavaccine/daikibosesshu.html (Tokyo vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008213628/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211004/k10013290701000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008213451/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291661000.html (third doses)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211002182806/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/

No change to previous policy.  The following preventative measures for the elderly continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Comprehensive information and training material for Long Term Care staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210920165410/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210920165631/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.html  https://archive.vn/Z2arL (http://kayoinoba.mhlw.go.jp/)  https://archive.vn/Qluha (https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00252.html)

Under this policy, banks and financial institutions that implement debt restructuring and new loan provisions benefited from regulatory forbearance on loan classification and provisioning. BOL also cut its policy rate from 4 to 3 percent for one-week loans; from 5 to 4 percent for one-two week loans; and from 10 to 9 percent for two-week to one-year loans. Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Laos? Yes    If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes    For information on limited humanitarian exemptions to U.S. Centers for Disease Controlâs (CDC) requirement that all U.S. bound travelers present a negative COVID-19 test  U.S. citizens can obtain a COVID-19 test in Laos at The National Center for Laboratory and Epidemiology (NCLE)  in Vientiane. The following information of U.S. citizens is needed to obtain a COVID-19 test: 1. Copy of Passport, 2. Itinerary, 3. A fee of 650,000 Lao kip (approximately $65) may be necessary for U.S. citizens. There are some exceptions to the cost of testing for diplomatic travelers.    A physical copy of test result will be available to pick up within 3 to 5 hours after collection of the sample (for urgent cases, results can be obtained within one hour)    The National Center for Laboratory and Epidemiology (NCLE) is the central authority for COVID-19 in Laos (tel: 021-312351.)  In order to be tested for COVID-19, you must qualify under the following testing criteria:    All new entrees to Laos;  People who have symptoms of COVID-19;  People with severe acute respiratory infection;  People who will travel abroad (and are approved by the Government of Laos COVID-19 Task Force)  There may be fees for each COVID-19 test of up 1.2 million Lao kip (approximately $130), depending on your visa class.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210913134902/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

On July 30, 2020, Burmese authorities updated implemented enhanced screening and quarantine measures to reduce the spread of COVID-19, to include the following:  All foreign nationals, including U.S. citizens, must first self-quarantine in their countries of origin for seven days, quarantine in a government facility or designated hotel upon arriving for another 14 days, and then self-quarantine at home for seven days.  These guidelines are subject to change without notice.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211011024056/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/     the Ministry of Health will lift temporary ban on residents of the Republic of India and the Peopleâs Republic of Bangladesh and travelers who had visited the Republic of India and the Peopleâs Republic of Bangladesh during the last 14 days, from visiting Myanmar. The measure will take effect starting from 24th September 2021, 2359 hours MST.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211011031806/https://www.mohs.gov.mm/page/17500

We are identifying those who have been in close contact with the patient for 2 days before the onset of symptoms and within 14 days after the onset of symptoms, based on the recommendations of the World Health Organization (WHOID).    The laboratory confirmed patients have close contact with his family and lived in their accommodation places, People who worked together Close contacts Strict home quarantine is being monitored for those who travel together during the trip. The participation of all members of the public, including family members, is especially needed in such monitoring.    The Ministry of Health and Sports is announcing the visit to public places within 2 days before the onset of symptoms and 14 days after the onset of the symptoms of laboratory confirmation patients, and urges the public who have been in contact with these patients to contact the nearest administration and health department as soon as possible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211009083727/https://mohs.gov.mm/page/8509
A mask must be worn at all times when outside the home.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211011024056/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

THE Ministry of Health conducts vaccination programmes in respective regions/states for target populations. Starting 26 July 2021, the ministry used Sinopharm and Sinovac vaccines donated by China and purchased from China to vaccinate the public for the first injection. For the second dose, the ministry distributed the vaccines via land or with the help of Tatmadaw (Air) and MAI to the remote areas starting 21 August 2021.    The vaccines were allocated to Mon, Kayin, Ayeyawady, Bago, Taninthayi, Shan, Magway, Sagaing, Mandalay, Nay Pyi Taw, Kachin and Rakhine until 25 August 2021.    These vaccines were also used to vaccinate the factory workers in Yangon, Mandalay, Bago and Ayeyawady regions. â MNA    https://web.archive.org/web/20211011034946/https://www.mdn.gov.mm/index.php/en/covid-19-vaccines-distributed-nationwide-second-injections

Travelers who have reached 14 days after vaccination should present their vaccination certificate if traveling into Ulaanbaatar from provinces. If provincial residents are traveling from provinces with registered case must present negative COVID-19 test received within the past 72 hours.  If traveling out of Ulaanbaatar to the provinces, travelers who have reached 14 days after vaccination must present their vaccination certificate at the provincial post. If not vaccinated, entry will be conditioned negative COVID-19 test received within the past 72 hours. Children under five will be entered based on guardianâs vaccination certificate, children above the five must present negative COVID-19 test received within the past 72 hours. Only one child above five should present negative test results representing other siblings.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210921015944/https://mn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The Philippines will reopen 120 schools for the first time since the pandemic began. Presidential spokesman Harry Roque announced this yesterday, specifying that this is a pilot project that does not yet include full reopening because the number of students and in-person classes will be limited.   "We have to pilot face-to-face (classes) because this is not just an issue for education, it's an issue for the children's mental health," he told reporters. "It's also an issue for the economy because we might lose a generation if we don't have face-to-face (classes)."  https://archive.ph/o91Vh

There is a pilot F2F project that will take from November 15th to 22nd December 2021. The F2F project will only apply to a limited number of schools.     Classes are openned depending on the level of alert in place. Currently under the strictest regulations (MECQ) applied, all classes are to be suspended. In other regions (GCQ and MGCQ) some classes are openned. Gatherings that are for the provision of critical government services and authorized humanitarian activities while adhering to the prescribed minimum health standards shall be allowed.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211005173328/https://www.covid19.gov.ph/security/mecq

The opening of workplaces depends on the level of restrictions. Under the strictest rules currently in place (MECQ) some establishments are required to be closed: entertainment, gyms, amusement industries, libraries, museums, cultural centers, personal care services, hotels.  Some establishments are at 50% of operational capacity such as: adminstrative, infant care supplies, clothing, flower and antique shops, malls.   Some establishment are at 100% of operational capacity such as: ariline, agriculture, forestry and fisheries, banks, construction, energy, food, health supply.    Under the level 4 alert zone: Except those located in areas covered by granular lockdowns, all other establishments, or activities not otherwise specified in Section 3(4) may be allowed to operate or be undertaken at 100% on-site or venue/seating capacity, provided they implement the minimum public health standards. However, they are encouraged to operate with a minimal on-site capacity necessary to implement full operations, while applying work-from-home and other flexible work arrangements.
